title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- More impressively, according to the National Cancer Institute, since 1992, the death rate from prostate cancer in the United States has dropped by an amazing 44% which is substantially due to PSA screenings resulting in earlier prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment.
content: Screening options include a digital rectal exam and a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test. Such screenings may lead to a biopsy with some associated risks. Transrectal ultrasound has no role in prostate cancer screenings. Routine screening with a DRE, and particularly PSA testing, has become very controversial. Here are some of the arguments for and against:
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- More impressively, according to the National Cancer Institute, since 1992, the death rate from prostate cancer in the United States has dropped by an amazing 44% which is substantially due to PSA screenings resulting in earlier prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. Screening options include a digital rectal exam and a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test. Such screenings may lead to a biopsy with some associated risks. Transrectal ultrasound has no role in prostate cancer screenings. Routine screening with a DRE, and particularly PSA testing, has become very controversial. Here are some of the arguments for and against:

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: There was no real change in overall survival for most patients for at least the first ten years after the initial diagnosis.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. There was no real change in overall survival for most patients for at least the first ten years after the initial diagnosis.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: Many patients (about three-quarters) are getting negative biopsies or show only low-risk disease, which is often overtreated.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. Many patients (about three-quarters) are getting negative biopsies or show only low-risk disease, which is often overtreated.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: Screenings are only likely to catch relatively slow-growing tumors and will miss the rapidly growing, aggressive tumors that are the most lethal.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. Screenings are only likely to catch relatively slow-growing tumors and will miss the rapidly growing, aggressive tumors that are the most lethal.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: Increased patient anxiety from low-risk, low-grade prostate cancer will ultimately not affect survival.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. Increased patient anxiety from low-risk, low-grade prostate cancer will ultimately not affect survival.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: "Unnecessary" biopsies contribute to patient anxiety, are uncomfortable, add cost, and may have complications like infections and bleeding.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. "Unnecessary" biopsies contribute to patient anxiety, are uncomfortable, add cost, and may have complications like infections and bleeding.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: Several recent large studies show little or no survival benefit to large-scale screenings.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. Several recent large studies show little or no survival benefit to large-scale screenings.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: As suggested by some recent studies (PIVOT), there is little point in doing prostate cancer screenings if treatment offers little or no survival benefit.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. As suggested by some recent studies (PIVOT), there is little point in doing prostate cancer screenings if treatment offers little or no survival benefit.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings
content: Foreign countries with good healthcare systems which do not perform widespread PSA testing have noted similar reductions in prostate cancer-specific survival compared to countries like the United States with extensive PSA screenings.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Against PSA Screenings. Foreign countries with good healthcare systems which do not perform widespread PSA testing have noted similar reductions in prostate cancer-specific survival compared to countries like the United States with extensive PSA screenings.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Prostate cancer is still the second leading cause of cancer death in men, and the incidence is increasing.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Prostate cancer is still the second leading cause of cancer death in men, and the incidence is increasing.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Ignoring our best diagnostic screening test for prostate cancer will not reduce its mortality.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Ignoring our best diagnostic screening test for prostate cancer will not reduce its mortality.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: We now have active surveillance, MRI imaging, and MRI-TRUS fusion biopsies, as well as genomic testing so that we can avoid overtreating patients.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. We now have active surveillance, MRI imaging, and MRI-TRUS fusion biopsies, as well as genomic testing so that we can avoid overtreating patients.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Eliminating routine PSA screenings, as recommended by the earlier USPSTF report of 2012, has already caused a significant reduction of about 30% in prostate cancer diagnoses. At least some of these cancers will ultimately be high-grade and will undoubtedly increase prostate cancer mortality.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Eliminating routine PSA screenings, as recommended by the earlier USPSTF report of 2012, has already caused a significant reduction of about 30% in prostate cancer diagnoses. At least some of these cancers will ultimately be high-grade and will undoubtedly increase prostate cancer mortality.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: A review of the SEER data indicated that the incidence of metastatic prostate cancer increased significantly immediately after the USPSTF recommendations against PSA testing were released. This increase was noted in all age groups and ethnicities. [470]
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. A review of the SEER data indicated that the incidence of metastatic prostate cancer increased significantly immediately after the USPSTF recommendations against PSA testing were released. This increase was noted in all age groups and ethnicities. [470]

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Many of the larger studies suggesting a lack of survival benefit to large-scale PSA screenings have been shown to be poorly done, significantly biased, severely contaminated, and full of major statistical errors.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Many of the larger studies suggesting a lack of survival benefit to large-scale PSA screenings have been shown to be poorly done, significantly biased, severely contaminated, and full of major statistical errors.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Well-done studies comparing PSA screened and unscreened populations clearly show a cancer-specific survival advantage consistently at or above 50% for the screened groups if followed for more than ten years.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Well-done studies comparing PSA screened and unscreened populations clearly show a cancer-specific survival advantage consistently at or above 50% for the screened groups if followed for more than ten years.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: According to the NIH, prostate cancer mortality has dropped over 44% since 1992, when PSA testing became widely available in the United States. This is almost double the benefit in foreign countries that do not perform extensive PSA testing.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. According to the NIH, prostate cancer mortality has dropped over 44% since 1992, when PSA testing became widely available in the United States. This is almost double the benefit in foreign countries that do not perform extensive PSA testing.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: The prostate cancer death rate in Sweden, where PSA testing is minimal, is higher than lung cancer and more than double the mortality rate for prostate cancer in the United States.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. The prostate cancer death rate in Sweden, where PSA testing is minimal, is higher than lung cancer and more than double the mortality rate for prostate cancer in the United States.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Long-term studies from Scandinavia and elsewhere prove that definitive treatment works, but it may take more than 10 to 15 years to become evident.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Long-term studies from Scandinavia and elsewhere prove that definitive treatment works, but it may take more than 10 to 15 years to become evident.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: It has been estimated by the NIH that in 10 years, an additional 25,000 to 30,000 men could die each year from preventable, potentially curable prostate cancer if we completely stopped all PSA screenings.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. It has been estimated by the NIH that in 10 years, an additional 25,000 to 30,000 men could die each year from preventable, potentially curable prostate cancer if we completely stopped all PSA screenings.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Only 9% of all new prostate cancer cases present with advanced disease, compared with 32% before the PSA era. This represents a 72% reduction.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Only 9% of all new prostate cancer cases present with advanced disease, compared with 32% before the PSA era. This represents a 72% reduction.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: Less than 4% of all new cases initially present with metastatic disease compared to 21% before widespread PSA screenings. This is an 80% reduction in the incidence of metastatic prostate cancer at the time of initial diagnosis that can only be explained by the benefits of PSA screenings.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. Less than 4% of all new cases initially present with metastatic disease compared to 21% before widespread PSA screenings. This is an 80% reduction in the incidence of metastatic prostate cancer at the time of initial diagnosis that can only be explained by the benefits of PSA screenings.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings
content: We are constantly improving diagnostic testing and treatment options to lower costs and minimize side effects while increasing survival and improving quality of life, but without early PSA screening, these new minimally invasive technologies cannot be used.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- In Favor of PSA Screenings. We are constantly improving diagnostic testing and treatment options to lower costs and minimize side effects while increasing survival and improving quality of life, but without early PSA screening, these new minimally invasive technologies cannot be used.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: An initial PSA test at 40 to 45 years of age is recommended because it is highly predictive of future prostate cancer risk, it provides a baseline, and it can help identify the rare but aggressive malignancies that appear prior to age 50.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. An initial PSA test at 40 to 45 years of age is recommended because it is highly predictive of future prostate cancer risk, it provides a baseline, and it can help identify the rare but aggressive malignancies that appear prior to age 50.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We recommend routine PSA screenings only in reasonably healthy men from 45 to 75 years of age who wish it after a frank discussion of the benefits, limitations, and potential risks of screening.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We recommend routine PSA screenings only in reasonably healthy men from 45 to 75 years of age who wish it after a frank discussion of the benefits, limitations, and potential risks of screening.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We do not recommend screening in patients who would not accept treatment even if cancer were found.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We do not recommend screening in patients who would not accept treatment even if cancer were found.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We do not recommend routine screening in healthy men over age 75 with normal PSA levels up to that point, as they are not likely to benefit from treatment.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We do not recommend routine screening in healthy men over age 75 with normal PSA levels up to that point, as they are not likely to benefit from treatment.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We encourage screening only in men who are reasonably expected to have at least a 10-year life expectancy from the time of diagnosis. (For most newly discovered localized prostate cancers, the survival benefit from treatment does not begin until at least ten years after therapy.)
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We encourage screening only in men who are reasonably expected to have at least a 10-year life expectancy from the time of diagnosis. (For most newly discovered localized prostate cancers, the survival benefit from treatment does not begin until at least ten years after therapy.)

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We encourage screening in men at high risk due to ethnicity, family history, or proven germline mutations.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We encourage screening in men at high risk due to ethnicity, family history, or proven germline mutations.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: We recommend PSA testing in men with an abnormal digital rectal examination suggestive of cancer regardless of age.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. We recommend PSA testing in men with an abnormal digital rectal examination suggestive of cancer regardless of age.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing
content: Finally, regardless of the above, we recommend doing PSA testing in all men who request it as long as they are fully aware of the risks, benefits, and limitations of screening, even if they fall outside the usual guidelines.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Recommended General Guide to PSA Testing. Finally, regardless of the above, we recommend doing PSA testing in all men who request it as long as they are fully aware of the risks, benefits, and limitations of screening, even if they fall outside the usual guidelines.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Pre-biopsy
content: Initial basic screening would include total PSA, free and total PSA, and PSA density levels. At least two separate PSA levels should be done before proceeding with more advanced testing. Some experts suggest using 4 to 6 weeks of a prostate-specific antibiotic (such as doxycycline, a fluoroquinolone, or sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim) between the two tests.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Pre-biopsy. Initial basic screening would include total PSA, free and total PSA, and PSA density levels. At least two separate PSA levels should be done before proceeding with more advanced testing. Some experts suggest using 4 to 6 weeks of a prostate-specific antibiotic (such as doxycycline, a fluoroquinolone, or sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim) between the two tests.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Pre-biopsy
content: Improved pre-biopsy "liquid biopsy" screening tests would include PCA3, the Prostate Health Index (PHI), MyProstateScore (MPS), the "4K" blood test, ExoDx or Exosome test, and SelectMDx. Overall, these tests have over 90% negative predictive value and can safely exclude about 25% of patients with persistently elevated PSA levels from further testing and unnecessary biopsies. They are best utilized prior to MRI imaging or a biopsy in men with persistently elevated PSA levels or as a confirmation after a negative MRI examination in borderline cases. [138] [471]
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Pre-biopsy. Improved pre-biopsy "liquid biopsy" screening tests would include PCA3, the Prostate Health Index (PHI), MyProstateScore (MPS), the "4K" blood test, ExoDx or Exosome test, and SelectMDx. Overall, these tests have over 90% negative predictive value and can safely exclude about 25% of patients with persistently elevated PSA levels from further testing and unnecessary biopsies. They are best utilized prior to MRI imaging or a biopsy in men with persistently elevated PSA levels or as a confirmation after a negative MRI examination in borderline cases. [138] [471]

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: A patient with a negative initial tissue biopsy being considered for a repeat prostatic biopsy can best be further analyzed and risk-stratified by tissue-based genomic bioassay such as ConfirmMDx.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. A patient with a negative initial tissue biopsy being considered for a repeat prostatic biopsy can best be further analyzed and risk-stratified by tissue-based genomic bioassay such as ConfirmMDx.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: Men on active surveillance can be tracked and followed with genomic testing or serial PCA3 testing in addition to standard PSA levels.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. Men on active surveillance can be tracked and followed with genomic testing or serial PCA3 testing in addition to standard PSA levels.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: Patients with low-grade or intermediate-grade disease being considered for either active surveillance or definitive therapy would benefit most from the Prolaris test.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. Patients with low-grade or intermediate-grade disease being considered for either active surveillance or definitive therapy would benefit most from the Prolaris test.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: Patients with low-grade or intermediate-grade disease considering radical prostatectomy can be evaluated with either the Decipher, Oncotype Dx Prostate, Prolaris, or ProMark test.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. Patients with low-grade or intermediate-grade disease considering radical prostatectomy can be evaluated with either the Decipher, Oncotype Dx Prostate, Prolaris, or ProMark test.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: Patients who are post-radiation therapy or diagnosed with prostate cancer after TURP surgery can best be tracked with the Prolaris genomic biomarker test.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. Patients who are post-radiation therapy or diagnosed with prostate cancer after TURP surgery can best be tracked with the Prolaris genomic biomarker test.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy
content: Overall prognosis, cancer-specific survival, and risk of metastases are best assessed in post-radical prostatectomy patients with a genomic test that serves as a prognostic marker of cancer control outcomes such as either Decipher or Prolaris.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Post-Biopsy. Overall prognosis, cancer-specific survival, and risk of metastases are best assessed in post-radical prostatectomy patients with a genomic test that serves as a prognostic marker of cancer control outcomes such as either Decipher or Prolaris.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Clinical Trials
content: Patients should be encouraged to consider participation in prostate cancer clinical trials whenever possible. These can be found at several locations. Cancer.org will present clinical trials in prostate cancer sponsored by the National Cancer Institute and the National Institute of Health. The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Consortium (PCCTC) is a clinical research group jointly sponsored by the Department of Defense Prostate Cancer Research Program and the Prostate Cancer Foundation. The coordinating center is located at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. There are 43 participating or affiliated clinical research sites. Information on the clinical trials available there can be found at pcf.org or pcctc.org.
contents: Prostate Cancer -- Pearls and Other Issues -- Clinical Trials. Patients should be encouraged to consider participation in prostate cancer clinical trials whenever possible. These can be found at several locations. Cancer.org will present clinical trials in prostate cancer sponsored by the National Cancer Institute and the National Institute of Health. The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Consortium (PCCTC) is a clinical research group jointly sponsored by the Department of Defense Prostate Cancer Research Program and the Prostate Cancer Foundation. The coordinating center is located at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. There are 43 participating or affiliated clinical research sites. Information on the clinical trials available there can be found at pcf.org or pcctc.org.

content: These and many more issues continue to challenge clinicians who deal with prostate cancer patients and men at risk for this common, potentially lethal male malignancy.

title: Prostate Cancer -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: The interprofessional team can optimize the treatment of these patients through communication and coordination of care. Primary care providers, urologists, oncologists, radiation oncologists, and nurse practitioners provide diagnoses and care plans. Specialty care urologic nurses should work with the team to coordinate care and be involved in patient education and monitoring compliance. The interprofessional team can thus improve outcomes for patients with prostate cancer. [Level 5]
